Award.AwardTitle: Investigation of near-Earth asteroid properties through a combination of infrared and radar observations
Award.AbstractNarration: This project will provide renewed support for the proposing team's work on the modeling of the surface properties of near-Earth asteroids (NEAs). The proposers have developed sophisticated computational methods for both constraining the shapes of NEAs from radar observations and for predicting the thermal infrared radiation emitted from their sunlit surfaces. By comparing the model predictions to observations obtained using space- and ground-based infrared telescopes, the team will be able to constrain the sizes and surface reflectivities (albedos) of the observed NEAs, as well as to test and refine the thermal models. The team plans to obtain radar observations of 6 to 10 NEAs per year in the 3-year term of the project, and to obtain infrared spectroscopic data for these objects and for objects with already-existing radar data. They will model the spectra using a "thermophysical" code that takes into account multiple important physical effects including heat conduction, shadowing, self-irradiation of the surface, and multiple scattering in the surface. The results will have wider implications for Solar System science, as thermal models are routinely used to infer the physical properties of small bodies. This study will enable a better quantification of the uncertainties in the sizes of NEAs and, therefore, a better assessment of the hazards from asteroid impacts on Earth. Educational opportunities for both students (K-12, undergraduate, and graduate) and teachers will be actively pursued through existing programs in place at the participating institutions.

Performance_Institution.Name: Johns Hopkins University Applied Physics Laboratory

POR.DRECONTENT:
With advances in the sensitivity of ground-based infrared (IR) instruments and survey missions such as Spitzer, WISE, and NEOWISE, the number of small bodies for which physical properties can be determined from thermal measurements is rapidly increasing. This data explosion is key to a more complete understanding of the overall asteroid population, but the ability to gather such data has outpaced the ability to analyze and interpret such observations in more than simple terms. Our goal was to make inroads into a greater understanding of what we can learn from thermal observations of asteroids. Specifically, we had two main objectives: 1) observe the thermal emission of a variety of asteroids at multiple viewing geometries and phase angles to build a unique database we could use to investigate their surface properties, and 2) develop a detailed thermophysical model and use it to carry out that investigation.

Over the course of this project, we observed over 30 near-Earth asteroids (NEAs) at NASA’s InfraRed Telescope Facility (IRTF). These observations spanned a variety of sizes, shapes, rotation periods, and compositional types, and were acquired over multiple observing geometries and phase angles, providing us with a valuable dataset for probing the properties of these smaller asteroids. Thermal modeling of asteroids to match the observations can reveal much about their surface properties, but the models most commonly in use are generally based on simplifying assumptions. Our observations demonstrated that these simple thermal models often do not self-consistently fit multiple observations of the same asteroid.

Because it is critical that we understand how and why the thermal emission behaves as it does, we developed a highly capable thermophysical model called SHERMAN. SHERMAN is able to use the actual shape of an asteroid as opposed to assuming it is a sphere or ellipsoid. The last decade has seen remarkable improvements in our capability to determine accurate shape models for small bodies using radar and lightcurve techniques. Using these shapes as input to SHERMAN, we were able to calculate the thermal emission more accurately, using our IR observations to constrain the models. By removing shape from the equation, we were able to disentangle the effects of other properties such as thermal inertia and surface roughness. This not only allowed a more complete study of the surface properties, it also allowed us to derive a better understanding of how thermal models apply to small, irregular asteroids in general.

Although spacecraft missions will always provide the most detailed look at asteroids, these missions are few and survey missions will continue to provide the bulk of small-body scientific data. To maximize the return from these large telescopic surveys, tools necessary for properly interpreting those surveys must be in place. Our results add significantly to the toolbox available to scientists, and they provide motivation for the use of crucial ground-based observations in support of existing missions and in target selection for future missions. This project was a powerful synthesis of complementary techniques  (IR, radar, lightcurves) and represented the type of interdisciplinary project that NSF fosters.

As part of this project, educational opportunities for both students and teachers were pursued. Three successful teacher workshops were conducted, bringing local teachers from all over Puerto Rico to Arecibo for a weekend to help enhance science in the classroom. The Arecibo Observatory currently has the only scientific outreach program in Puerto Rico and reaches a large portion of the Hispanic community there. Continued teacher education programs help to increase the visibility of science careers for Puerto Rican students. We also supported the Arecibo Space Academy, which brought local high school students together for several weekends to learn about space and motivate them to pursue careers in science. Finally, we have two graduate students participating in the project, so we are training the next generation of scientists.
